label: thm-mean-field-equation
title: The Mean-Field Equations for the Euclidean Gas
nl_statement: The evolution of the Euclidean Gas in the mean-field limit is governed by a coupled system of equations for the alive density $f(t,z)$ and the dead mass $m_d(t)$, which includes an equation for $f$ involving $L^\dagger$, killing rate $c(z)$, revival $B$, and cloning $S$, and an ODE for $m_d(t)$ describing the rate of transition from alive to dead mass and mass revival from the dead pool, subject to the constraint $m_a(t) + m_d(t) = 1$.

equations.label: eq-mean-field-pde-main
equations.latex: \partial_t f = L^\dagger f - c(z)f + B[f, m_d] + S[f]

hypotheses.text: Initial condition for alive density: $f(0, \cdot) = f_0$
Initial condition for dead mass: $m_d(0) = 1 - \int_\Omega f_0$

conclusion.text: The system conserves the total population: $m_a(t) + m_d(t) = 1$ for all $t$.

label: thm-mass-conservation
title: Total Mass Conservation and Population Dynamics
nl_statement: For any sufficiently regular solution $(f(t,z), m_d(t))$ to the Mean-Field Equations, the total population $m_a(t) + m_d(t)$ is conserved, and the alive population $m_a(t)$ evolves according to the balance between revival and killing.

hypotheses.text: $(f(t,z), m_d(t))$ is a sufficiently regular solution to the Mean-Field Equations.
The total population is conserved for all time $t>0$. (If $m_a(0) + m_d(0) = 1$, then $m_a(t) + m_d(t) = 1$ for all $t$.)
The alive mass evolves according to the balance between killing and revival.

conclusion.text: Total mass is conserved: $\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}t}\left[m_a(t) + m_d(t)\right] = 0$. The alive mass changes as $\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}t}m_a(t) = \lambda_{\text{rev}} m_d(t) - k_{\text{killed}}[f](t)$.

implicit_assumptions.text: The domain $\Omega$ is the state space over which $f$ is defined.
The Mean-Field Equations are the governing dynamical equations for $f$ and $m_d$.
Regularity of the solution $(f(t,z), m_d(t))$ is sufficient to allow differentiation and integration as written.

label: thm-killing-rate-consistency
title: Consistency of the Interior Killing Rate Approximation
nl_statement: Under specific regularity assumptions, a smooth killing rate function $c$ exists, which satisfies pointwise convergence for the discrete exit rate to $c(x,v)$ (Part i), and yields a consistency between the discrete and continuous expected killing fractions, accompanied by a specific error bound (Part ii).

constraints: \text{depends only on } M_f, M_{\nabla f}, M_F, C_R, \text{ and the geometry of } X_{\text{valid}}

implicit_assumptions.text: The domain $\Omega$ is a subset of $\mathbb{R}^d$.
The distance function $d(x)$ refers to the distance to the boundary of $X_{\text{valid}}$.
The set $\mathcal{T}_\delta$ is related to the boundary layer within distance $\delta$ of the boundary.

label: thm-mean-field-limit-informal
title: Mean-Field Limit (Informal Statement)
nl_statement: The empirical density $f_N^\tau(t, x, v)$ of the $N$-particle discrete Fragile Gas dynamics converges weakly to the mean-field density $f(t, x, v)$ as $N \to \infty$ and $\tau \to 0$ (with $\tau = O(N^{-\alpha})$ for $\alpha > 0$), where $f$ solves the associated mean-field PDE.

equations.latex: f_N^\tau(t, x, v) := \frac{1}{N} \sum_{i=1}^N \delta(x - X_i^\tau(t), v - V_i^\tau(t))

hypotheses.text: $(X_i^\tau(t), V_i^\tau(t))_{i=1}^N$ is the $N$-particle discrete Fragile Gas dynamics with timestep $\tau$.
The limit is taken in the joint limit $N \to \infty, \tau \to 0$ with $\tau = O(N^{-\alpha})$ for $\alpha > 0$.

conclusion.text: $f_N^\tau(t, \cdot, \cdot)$ converges weakly to $f(t, \cdot, \cdot)$, where $f$ solves the mean-field PDE (Equations [](#eq-mean-field-pde-main) and [](#eq-dead-mass-ode)).

implicit_assumptions.text: The weak convergence is typically in a suitable space, e.g., $L^p$ or bounded measures.
The convergence rate $\tau = O(N^{-\alpha})$ for $\alpha > 0$ ensures the time discretization error is compensated by the particle number growth.
